name: "Teen Titans": The Early Adventures Multiple Choice Quiz | Entertainment | 10 Questions

questions.text: Which of these were not in the original team, as of the first issue of "Teen Titans"?
questions.explanation:
Beast Boy.

	In the first issue of their own book, the four Titans were Robin, Aqualad, Kid Flash and Wonder Girl. It was revealed that Speedy was a founding member in the fifty-fourth issue.

questions.text: When did Speedy make his first appearance in the comic?
questions.explanation:
Issue Four.

	Responding to fan mail, the writers of the book included Speedy in an adventure during the summer Olympics in the fourth issue. Speedy was slated to fire arrows through the five Olympic rings at the opening ceremony.

questions.text: Beast Boy tried to join the Titans, but he couldn't. What did one need to join?
options: An ID card of some kind
questions.explanation:
Their legal guardian's permission.

	Beast Boy couldn't join the Titans because his legal guardian wouldn't give him permission. Sadly, he couldn't join the Doom Patrol for the same exact reason!

questions.text: In their first issue, the Teen Titans battled three animals with the same face! Which of these animals was not featured?
questions.explanation:
Shark.

	The Beast-God(s) of Xochatan were three spirit beasts who attacked the Teen Titans. If that wasn't enough, the foursome also had to defeat a huge robot conquistador!

questions.text: In their second issue, the Titans met a teenager who was approximately one million years old! What was his name?
questions.explanation:
Garn.

	Garn was a caveman who had been frozen in ice until the present day. His nemesis, Akkuru. Akkuru wielded a magic axe, while Garn's weapon of choice was a spear. Garn had above-average comprehension of the English language for a caveman.

questions.text: Ding-Dong Daddy was a villain who ran a car repair shop, and used the cars to commit crimes! What was unique about his hiring methods?
options: He hired teens who looked alike
questions.explanation:
He hired drop-outs.

	It got to the point that students were dropping out of school just to work for Ding Dong Daddy! Luckily, after Daddy was busted by the Titans, the students were convinced to give school another try.

questions.text: One of the Titans' recurring villains is the Mad Mod. He showed up first in Issue Seven. What nationality is this ne'er-do-well?
questions.explanation:
British.

	The Mad Mod often referred  to people as "laddio" and "ducky". Luckily he was caught by the Titans before he could maul the English language even more. He has returned several times to battle the Titans, and was a villain on the "Teen Titans" television show.

questions.text: All the Titans except Robin were once thrown into a dimension known as Limbo. Who is the ruler of Limbo?
questions.explanation:
Gargoyle.

	The Gargoyle ruled over Limbo, and had an unspecified grudge against the team. He accused one of the Titans of knowing he was innocent of a past crime, but they supposedly kept the proof under wraps. Robin was eventually able to beat him in combat and free his teammates.

questions.text: The Titans villain who lifted international monuments with a ray gun was known as the Transporter.
questions.explanation:
False.

	The villain's name was the Deliverer. He nearly succeeded in lifting Mount Rushmore into orbit, and got even closer to his goal with the Sphinx of Egypt. Working for aliens, he was apprehended by the Titans, who were tipped off by a DJ in space who was being held hostage by the same aliens.

questions.text: In their first holiday issue, the plot followed this classic tale.
questions.explanation:
A Christmas Carol.

	In their December issue, the Teen Titans met characters by the name of Scrounge and his hard-working but poor employee, Ratchit. Of course, these characters were based on Ebeneezer Scrooge and Bob Cratchit. Happily, everything is resolved by the last page.
